Name:
Jupiter (1912–1920)
Langley (1920–1942)

Langley-class aircraft carrier
Cost:
$1,326,111.36 (Jupiter Hull and Machinery)
$395,992.80 (Repairs, changes and alterations to June 30, 1919)[1]
Reclassified:
Fleet carrier, 21 April 1920
Seaplane tender, 21 April 1937
Identification:
Hull symbol: AC-3
Hull symbol: CV-1
Hull symbol: AV-3
awards:
As Jupiter: 

Mexican Service Medal
World War I Victory Medal ("Transport" clasp)

As Langley: 

American Defense Service Medal ("Fleet" clasp)
Asiatic–Pacific Campaign Medal
World War II Victory Medal
Fate: Scuttled after Japanese air attack, 27 February 1942
Built:
1920 (converted to an aircraft carrier)
1936 (converted to a seaplane tender)
In commission:
1922–1936 (as an aircraft carrier)
1937–1942 (as a Seaplane tender)
Displacement:
19,360 long tons (19,670 t) (as Jupiter)
12,700 long tons (12,900 t) (standard, as Langley)[2]
13,900 long tons (14,100 t) (full load, as Langley)[2]
Draft:
27 ft 8 in (8.4 m) (as Jupiter)
24 ft (7.3 m) (as Langley)[2]
Complement:
163 officers and men (as Jupiter)
468 officers and men (as Langley)
Armament:
4 × 4 in (102 mm)/50 cal guns (as Jupiter)
4 × 5 in (127 mm)/51 cal guns (as Langley)
